results.title: Glass cinema slides
results.brief_description: These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, as well as the changing face of cinema when the Motion Picture Production Code was established.

constellations_primary.name: Wearing the pants, ladies who lead
constellations_primary.description: The pre-code 1932 feature, A Bill of Divorcement, a glass cinema slide of which features in the glass cinema slide display, stars John Barrymore and Katharine Hepburn in her screen debut.

results.description: Hollywood studios spent a lot of money transitioning to talkies. To recoup the cost, they produced salacious films to attract big audiences. People certainly responded – including conservative groups, who pressured studios to protect family values. The Motion Picture Production Code was established in 1930 as a response but wasn’t enforced until 1934. These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, including A Bill of Divorcement (1932), which flouted the production code by exploring a marriage breakdown, as well as John Ford’s The World Moves On (1934), the first film to receive a Motion Pictures Producers and Distributors of America (now MPAA) certificate under the new Production Code.
description_for_label: Hollywood studios spent a lot of money transitioning to talkies. To recoup the cost, they produced salacious films to attract big audiences. People certainly responded – including conservative groups, who pressured studios to protect family values. The Motion Picture Production Code was established in 1930 as a response but wasn’t enforced until 1934. These glass slides advertise films that charted the change from silent to sound cinema, including A Bill of Divorcement (1932), which flouted the production code by exploring a marriage breakdown, as well as John Ford’s The World Moves On (1934), the first film to receive a Motion Pictures Producers and Distributors of America (now MPAA) certificate under the new Production Code.

results.title: Glass
results.creator_credit: Frank Worth, Cecil Musk and Pilkington Brothers
results.brief_description: An ancient Roman comes to life and tours the Pilkington glassworks. He discovers modern methods of manufacture and the wide range of uses for glass products; in aviation, at home, in industry, science and building. Each item’s use and manufacture is demonstrates (with a streak of comedy to lighten the approach) including the grinding and polishing of lenses, the medieval technique of making glass by hand and mechanical glass blowing.

results.title: Glass
results.brief_description: Portrays without commentary the deft craftsmanship of glass blowers, highlighting the artistry and individuality of their work. Contrasts this with machines which produce bottles and glass jars automatically.

results.title: Glasgow 1980
results.creator_credit: Oscar Marzaroli, City of Glascow, Films of Scotland and Ogam Films
results.brief_description: The urban renewal of Glasgow. The biggest urban renewal in Europe. A 20 year program begun in 1960 involving 550 miles or one twelth of the City area. Shows what has been achieved and what will be achieved by 1980. Editing by Bill Forsyth. Narrated by Michael Harrigan.

results.title: Gladiator [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ridley Scott, Branko Lustig, David Franzoni, Douglas Wick, NBCUniversal and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Following the suspicious death of Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius, his newly named successor, Maximus (Russell Crowe) - the former emperor’s key advisor and most loyal general, is accused of his murder, leaving Marcus’ scheming son, Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) to take over the throne. As a result of his accusation, Maximus is stripped of his title and position in the army and sold to slave traders, forced to become a gladiator - men trained to fight to the death as entertainment for a paying audience. Using his new fame and power he vows to fight the man responsible for his dishonour. Includes the making of documentary. Cast also includes Connie Nielsen, Derek Jacobi, Richard Harris and Oliver Reed in his final screen role (Reed died before the movie was completed). Awards: winner of 5 Academy Awards including Best Actor (Russell Crowe) and Best Film (2000).

results.title: Glaciers
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Presents the properties of glaciers and assesses their importance in sculpting Earth’s surface. The study of glacial movement is important in determining the impact of the Greenhouse Effect. By studying the cyclic nature of Ice Ages, geologists can assist scientists in predicting rising sea levels. There are two types of glaciers; valley glaciers which move from mountains down to valleys and continental glaciers which are single giant ice sheets which accumulate in doems on the surface of the planet.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television

results.title: Glaciers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Understanding Our Earth”.
Shows the formation of many different types glaciers and describes the effect of glacial action as seen in the lakes of the Rockies, soil in the American Corn Belt, glacial drift in new England, and the Matterhorn peak in the Swiss Alps.
